p: Recent outbreaks in Angola, Nigeria and Brazil have shown that yellow fever (YF) remains a significant public health threat [ 1, 2]. The epidemics of Zika and chikungunya in Latin America have also highlighted the risks of international spread of arboviruses. The spread of YF to Asia, where the virus has not yet been detected despite the presence of competent vectors, could have a major negative public health impact [ 3, 4]. In response, in 2016, the World Health Organisation (WHO) adopted a strategy to Eliminate Yellow fever Epidemics (EYE) by 2026. This strategy aims to prevent sporadic cases sparking urban outbreaks, thus minimizing the risk of international spread [ 5]. The EYE strategy largely relies on, but is not limited to, scale-up of vaccination.
